Name: PGP Public Key
Regex:
^(?:-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
?(?:(?:(?:Version|Comment|MessageID|Hash|Charset):.*)
?)*[a-zA-Z0-9/\.
\:\+\=]+-----END PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----)$

Valid: -----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----Comment: Alice's OpenPGP certificateComment: https://www.ietf.org/id/draft-bre-openpgp-samples-01.-----END PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----

Name: PGP Private Key
Regex:
^(?:-----BEGIN PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----
?(?:(?:(?:Version|Comment|MessageID|Hash|Charset):.*)
?)*[a-zA-Z0-9/\.
\:\+\=]+-----END PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----)$

Valid: -----BEGIN PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----Comment: Alice's OpenPGP Transferable Secret KeyComment: https://www.ietf.org/id/draft-bre-openpgp-samples-01.-----END PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----

Name: PEM-formatted Private Key
Regex: ^(-----BEGIN( ANY| RSA| DSA| ENCRYPTED| EC| OPENSSH)? PRIVATE KEY-----\n?[a-zA-Z0-9\/\.\n\:\+\=]+-----END( ANY| RSA| DSA| ENCRYPTED| EC| OPENSSH)? PRIVATE KEY-----)$

Name: TryHackMe Flag Format
Description: Used for Capture The Flags at https://tryhackme.com

Name: HackTheBox Flag Format
Description: Used for Capture The Flags at https://hackthebox.eu

Name: Heroku API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid:
  $ curl -X POST https://api.heroku.com/apps -H "Accept: application/vnd.heroku+json; version=3" -H "Authorization: Bearer API_KEY_HERE"

Name: Slack API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid:
  $ curl -sX POST "https://slack.com/api/auth.test?token=API_KEY_HERE&pretty=1"

Name: Slack Webhook
Exploit:
If the command below returns 'missing_text_or_fallback_or_attachments', it means
that the URL is valid, any other responses would mean that the URL is invalid.
  $ curl -s -X POST -H "Content-type: application/json" -d '{"text":""}' "SLACK_WEBOOK_URL_HERE"

Name: Amazon Web Services Simple Storage (AWS S3) URL
Amazon Web Services Simple Storage (AWS S3) Internal URL
Description: Internal URL, only accessible via the virtual private cloud.

Name: Square Application Secret
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the secret is valid:
  $ curl "https://squareup.com/oauth2/revoke" -d '{"access_token":"[RANDOM_STRING]","client_id":"[APP_ID]"}'  -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: Client SECRET_HERE"

Name: Square Access Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the access token is valid:
  $ curl https://connect.squareup.com/v2/locations -H "Authorization: Bearer TOKEN_HERE"

Name: Stripe API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid:
  $ curl https://api.stripe.com/v1/charges -u "API_KEY_HERE:"

Name: GitHub Access Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the access token is valid:
  $ curl -s -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" https://api.github.com/user
  curl -s -H "Authorization: token TOKEN_HERE" "https://api.github.com/users/[USERNAME]/orgs"
 . # Check scope of your api token
 $  curl "https://api.github.com/rate_limit" -i -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" | grep "X-OAuth-Scopes:"

Name: Facebook Secret Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the secret key is valid:
  $ curl "https://graph.facebook.com/oauth/access_token?client_id=[ID]&client_secret=SECRET_KEY_HERE&redirect_uri=&grant_type=client_credentials"

Name: Facebook Client ID
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the secret key is valid:
  $ curl "https://graph.facebook.com/oauth/access_token?client_id=ID_HERE&client_secret=[SECRET_KEY]&redirect_uri=&grant_type=client_credentials"

Name: Twitter Secret API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid:
  $ curl -u 'API key:API_KEY_HERE' --data 'grant_type=client_credentials' 'https://api.twitter.com/oauth2/token'

Name: GitHub Personal Access Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the access token is valid:
  $ curl -s -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" https://api.github.com/user
  curl -s -H "Authorization: token TOKEN_HERE" "https://api.github.com/users/[USERNAME]/orgs"
 . # Check scope of your api token
 $  curl "https://api.github.com/rate_limit" -i -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" | grep "X-OAuth-Scopes:"

Name: GitHub OAuth Access Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the access token is valid:
  $ curl -s -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" https://api.github.com/user
  curl -s -H "Authorization: token TOKEN_HERE" "https://api.github.com/users/[USERNAME]/orgs"
 . # Check scope of your api token
 $  curl "https://api.github.com/rate_limit" -i -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" | grep "X-OAuth-Scopes:"

Name: GitHub App Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the app token is valid:
  $ curl -s -u "user:TOKEN_HERE" https://api.github.com/user
  curl -s -H "Authorization: token TOKEN_HERE" "https://api.github.com/users/[USERNAME]/orgs"
 . # Check scope of your api token

Name: Stripe Standard API Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the Stripe Standard Live API Token is valid.
  $ curl https://api.stripe.com/v1/charges -u TOKEN_HERE:

Keep the colon at the end of the token to prevent cURL from requesting a password.

The live key can be used to extract/retrieve a lot of info ranging from the charges
to the complete product list.

Keep in mind that you will never be able to get the full credit card information since
Stripe only gives you the last 4 digits.

Name: Square OAuth Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the token is valid:
  $ curl "https://squareup.com/oauth2/revoke" -d '{"access_token":"[RANDOM_STRING]","client_id":"[APP_ID]"}'  -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: Client TOKEN_HERE"

Name: SendGrid Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the SendGrid Token is valid.
  $ curl -X "GET" "https://api.sendgrid.com/v3/scopes" -H "Authorization: Bearer SENDGRID_TOKEN_HERE" -H "Content-Type: application/json"

Name: Zapier Webhook Token
Exploit:
Verify that the Zapier Webook url is valid:
  curl -H "Accept: application/json" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X POST -d '{"name":"PyWhat"}' "WEBHOOK_URL_HERE"

Name: New Relic Admin API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that API key is valid:
  $ curl -X POST https://api.newrelic.com/graphql -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'API-Key: API_KEY_HERE' -d '{ "query": "{ requestContext { userId apiKey } }" } '

Name: New Relic REST API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the New Relic REST API Key is valid.
  $ curl -X GET 'https://api.newrelic.com/v2/applications.json' -H "X-Api-Key:${API_KEY_HERE}" -i

If valid, test furher to see if its an admin key (https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/intro-apis/new-relic-api-keys/)

Name: New Relic User API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that API key is valid:
  $ curl -X POST https://api.newrelic.com/graphql -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'API-Key: API_KEY_HERE' -d '{ "query": "{ requestContext { userId apiKey } }" } '

Name: PyPI Upload Token
Exploit: Anyone with this token is able to upload to the PyPI for the package that belongs to this token.

Name: CIFS Fstab Entry With Clear Credentials
Mailchimp API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid (substitute <dc> for your datacenter, i. e. us5):
  $ curl --request GET --url 'https://<dc>.api.mailchimp.com/3.0/' --user 'anystring:API_KEY_HERE' --include

Name: Notion Integration Token
Description: A Notion API integration's internal integration token.

Name: Bitly Secret Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the secret key is valid:
  $ curl "https://api-ssl.bitly.com/v3/shorten?access_token=SECRET_KEY_HERE&longUrl=https://www.google.com"

Name: Visual Studio App Center API Token
United States Postal Service (UPS) Tracking Number
Turkish License Plate Number
Description: The [#CAE4F1][link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Turkey]vehicle registration plate number of Turkey[/link][/#CAE4F1]

Name: Slack Token
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that private key is valid:
  $ curl -sX POST "https://slack.com/api/auth.test?token=TOKEN_HERE&pretty=1"

Name: Google API Key
Exploit:
There is a change this could be a Google Maps API key, so could try using 'gmapapiscanner'[1] or 'gap'[2]
to check which Google Maps service it is valid for and generate a PoC that you can show in your report. To
get a better understanding on the severity of having the Google Maps API key exposed, make sure to to to
read "Unauthorized Google Maps API Key Usage Cases, and Why You Need to Care"[3] written by Ozgur Alp (@ozguralp)

References:
 [1] https://github.com/ozguralp/gmapsapiscanner
 [2] https://github.com/joanbono/gap
 [3] https://ozguralp.medium.com/unauthorized-google-maps-api-key-usage-cases-and-why-you-need-to-care-1ccb28bf21e

API Documentation: https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/get-api-key

Name: Mailgun API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that private key is valid:
  $ curl --user 'api:key-PRIVATE_KEY_HERE' "https://api.mailgun.net/v3/domains"

Name: Twilio API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that API key is valid:
  $ curl -X GET 'https://api.twilio.com/2010-04-01/Accounts.json' -u [ACCOUNT_SID]:AUTH_TOKEN_HERE

Name: Twilio Account SID
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the SID is valid:
  $ curl -X GET 'https://api.twilio.com/2010-04-01/Accounts.json' -u ACCOUNT_SID_HERE:[AUTH_TOKEN]

Name: Google ReCaptcha API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that API key is valid:
  $ curl -X POST -d "secret=API_KEY_HERE&response=RESPONSE_TO_VERIFY" https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api/siteverify

Name: Amazon Web Services Access Key
Exploit:
Install awscli (https://aws.amazon.com/cli/), set the access key and secret to environment variables, and execute the following command: $ AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=ACCESS_KEY_HERE AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=[SECRET_KEY] aws sts get-caller-identity
 AWS credentials' permissions can be determined using enumerate-IAM (https://github.com/andresriancho/enumerate-iam).
 This gives broader view of the discovered AWS credentials privileges instead of just checking S3 buckets.
 $ git clone https://github.com/andresriancho/enumerate-iam
  cd  enumerate-iam
  ./enumerate-iam.py --access-key ACCESS_KEY_HERE --secret-key [SECRET_KEY]

Name: Amazon Web Services Secret Access Key
Exploit:
Install awscli (https://aws.amazon.com/cli/), set the access key and secret to environment variables, and execute the following command: $ AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=[ACCESS_KEY] AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=SECRET_KEY_HERE aws sts get-caller-identity
 AWS credentials' permissions can be determined using enumerate-IAM (https://github.com/andresriancho/enumerate-iam).
 This gives broader view of the discovered AWS credentials privileges instead of just checking S3 buckets.
 $ git clone https://github.com/andresriancho/enumerate-iam
  cd  enumerate-iam
  ./enumerate-iam.py --access-key [ACCESS_KEY] --secret-key SECRET_KEY_HERE

Name: Amazon Web Services EC2 Instance ID
Recent Unix Timestamp
Description: Seconds elapsed since unix epoch: 1970, between year 2001 and 2286

Name: Recent Unix Millisecond Timestamp
Description: Milliseconds elapsed since unix epoch: 1970, between year 2001 and 2286

Name: Datadog API Key
Exploit:
Use the command below to verify that the API key is valid:
